title: Should Systematic Reviewers Search for Randomized, Controlled Trials Published as Letters?
abstract: Letters6 May 2008Should Systematic Reviewers Search for Randomized, Controlled Trials Published as Letters?Alla E. Iansavichene, MLIS, Margaret Sampson, MLIS, Jessie McGowan, MLIS, and Isola S.Y. Ajiferuke, PhDAlla E. Iansavichene, MLISFrom London Health Sciences Centre and University of Western Ontario, London, Ontario, Canada, and Children's Hospital of Eastern Ontario Research Institute and Institute of Population Health, University of Ottawa, Ottawa, Ontario, Canada.Search for more papers by this author, Margaret Sampson, MLISFrom London Health Sciences Centre and University of Western Ontario, London, Ontario, Canada, and Children's Hospital of Eastern Ontario Research Institute and Institute of Population Health, University of Ottawa, Ottawa, Ontario, Canada.Search for more papers by this author, Jessie McGowan, MLISFrom London Health Sciences Centre and University of Western Ontario, London, Ontario, Canada, and Children's Hospital of Eastern Ontario Research Institute and Institute of Population Health, University of Ottawa, Ottawa, Ontario, Canada.Search for more papers by this author, and Isola S.Y. Ajiferuke, PhDFrom London Health Sciences Centre and University of Western Ontario, London, Ontario, Canada, and Children's Hospital of Eastern Ontario Research Institute and Institute of Population Health, University of Ottawa, Ottawa, Ontario, Canada.Search for more papers by this authorAuthor, Article, and Disclosure Informationhttps://doi.org/10.7326/0003-4819-148-9-200805060-00023 SectionsAboutFull TextPDF ToolsAdd to favoritesDownload CitationsTrack CitationsPermissions ShareFacebookTwitterLinkedInRedditEmail Background: A report by Deeks and Altman (1) found randomized, controlled trials (RCTs) published as letters to be incompletely reported and noncompliant with the Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials (CONSORT). The authors recommended that journals reexamine their policies of publishing RCTs as short reports.We examined RCTs published as letters before and after these recommendations. Our interest stems from our involvement in information retrieval for systematic reviews. A rigorous search strategy is a key component in identifying evidence (2), because an inadequate search strategy could result in missed studies and misleading conclusions. Yet, these searches often exclude certain publication types, ...References1. Deeks JJ, Altman DG. Inadequate reporting of controlled trials as short reports [Letter]. Lancet. 1998;352:1908. [PMID: 9863796] CrossrefMedlineGoogle Scholar2. Moher D, Cook DJ, Eastwood S, Olkin I, Rennie D, Stroup DF.
